Def.Name: Bigtooth Aspen
Def.Description: Medium/large tree growing 50' - 100' tall and 2' wide. Open, round crown with ascending branches. Usually long straight trunk.
Def.Leaves: Simple, alternate, 3" - 6" long and 1" - 3" wide. Shiny and solid with coarse toothed margins. Teeth may be really curved. Yellow/green in color turing yellow in autumn. May have flat leafstalk.
Def.Twigs: Gray/green - orange/brown with orange lenticels (dots), hairy. Has a star shaped pith. Buds may be pointed and hairy.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Fruit: Capsule, with lots of seeds that have cotton like hairs. 3" - 6" catkins around late spring.
Def.Bark: Orange/white to olive-green to gray and relatively smooth; bark of old trees is more furrowed, rough-textured, and gray-brown.
Def.Range: Native to North America, found mostly in the North Eastern United States and South Eastern Canada.
Def.Remarks: Mature trees are damaged by wildfires because of their thin bark. Big-Toothed Aspen can rapidly spread after a wildlife because clonal trees soon develop from underground runners.
